trial_identification.studytitle: Understanding How Anaesthesia Affects ECT Outcomes
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Understanding How Anaesthesia Affects ECT Outcomes

interventions.interventions:
Other interventions - Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) time interval + Anaesthetic (Thiopentone)
Active Comparator: Short time interval + Normal ventilation -
Active Comparator: Short time interval + Hyperventilation -
Active Comparator: Long time interval + Normal ventilation -
Active Comparator: Long time interval + Hyperventilation -
Other interventions: Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) time interval + Anaesthetic (Thiopentone) The intervention in this study is the time interval between anaesthetic administration and ECT stimulus

primaryOutcome.outcome: EEG Seizure Quality Rating using the EEG Seizure Quality Rating Sheet utilised by MacPherson et al - EEG quality will be rated manually for each ECT treatment undertaken by a participant until the conclusion of their ECT course. This rating will be done using the EEG Seizure Quality Rating Sheet utilised by MacPherson et al - low dose lignocaine added to propofol does not attenuate the response to electroconvulsive therapy; Journal of Affective Disorders, 2010; 126: 330-333
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Outcome measures will be collected immediately after each ECT treatment from the first treatment until the end of the ECT course, an estimated total of four to six weeks for most participants

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: - Patients treated with a course of ECT
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: - Use of non-standard anaesthetic agents in ECT (e.g. ketamine)

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The University of New South Wales

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will examine how anaesthetic technique affects ECT outcomes. Specifically, the investigators will examine how: 1) the time interval between anaesthetic and ECT stimulus, and 2) the ventilation rate before ECT stimulus, impacts on the quality of the EEG (this is a recording of brain activity during ECT and is used to judge the quality of a seizure and to guide individual patient dosing).

contact.name: Colleen Loo, MBBS
contact.address: The University of New South Wales
